text: EBF 2017. Pours a pretty clear medium brown with a small white head that leaves pretty nice lacing. Nose is of something that burnt, bread crust in fact, weird. Taste is of chocolate spread, whole wheat bread, just fake. Moderately bitter. Body and carbonation are medium and it feels a bit sticky. Overall a weird one that doesnt bring all that much enjoyment to me. Just fake like (almost) all the FB brews Ive had so far.

on tap at extreme beer fest 2017, boston. unclear medium dark brown, copper-orange with a small light beige cap offering some retention and lacing. outrageous peanut and raspberry aroma, burnt/roasted peanuts, sweet white loaf, brown caramelized maltiness, not much else, really. moderately carbonation, medium body - oily and kind of heavy; sweet jammy finish. another ridiculous offering from FB, although mimicking exactly peanut butter and jelly.

Draft at EBF 2017. How to rate this beer? If I think of it as a brown ale (or really any ale), it is way off the mark. It smells like peanut butter and chocolate and then tastes like raspberry jam. But, I cant help being impressed by the innovation and wacky creativity that went into this. It really tastes like a PB&J sandwich, and while that may make other people ding points, I was pleasantly surprised.

On tap @ Copenhagen Beer Celebration 2014. This is a soft clouded deep amber almost a little brown looking one with a nice quickly sidesticking and lacing beige head. It smells like soft fruits, fruity fresh raspberries and strawberry jam. Some wood also in here. It tastes quite nice. Soft wood dry with some strong tartness Im having problems identifying. A blend of sour cherries and raspberries? Almost a little astringent. Lots of raspberries toward the finish with that little sour tone making it interesting. Quite decent this. A fruity one and really different! 03.05.2014

Sampled at Copenhagen Beer Celebration 2014. Session 4. Pours clear amber with a creamy, white head. Tasty, with notes of berries, peanuts. Pretty good balance, moderately sweet. Medium bodied with fine to average carbonation. Finishes with more fruity character and impressions of peanut butter. Novel. Not bad.
An amber beer with a beige head. The aroma has notes of malt, caramel, and alcohol. The flavor is acidic with notes of malt, brettanomyces, lemons, leading to a tart finish.

Like most funky Buddha offerings, this one is overly sweet but it's a fun beer otherwise.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Draft at the brewery. Pours clear copper brown with a fizzy beige head. Tastes like sweet chocolate, peanut butter, grape and strawberry jelly, and roasted chocolate malt. Light/medium body and low carbonation. Smells like rich peanut butter, grape jelly, and some roasted chocolate malt.

Brown with almost no head. Edges are golden to Amber. Aroma is absolute ridiculous its not butter and jelly sandwich, my childhood in a glass. Roasted peanuts along with a little bit saltiness, like dry roasted, some jellies, like strawberry or raspberry, and a toasty grainy bread-like. Its really spectacular that all the aromas are so noticeable. Flavor is a little more muddled, some caramel and light chocolates, berries and nutty peanuts, smooth, sweet malts. Moderate to fuller sweetness. Light Cocoa flavors maybe. Its really impressive. 21112015

Sampled at Pinocchios. Amber tan pour with nice head. Okay. It smells like peanut butter. Tastes like a moderate brown ale - caramel malts, dry on the tongue - infused with peanut butter. Okay as a gimmick, but really too odd to be worth much of anything.

On tap at Funky Buddha poured a clear reddish brown with a small lingering tan head. Aromas of peanut butter, jelly and light bread. Palate was light bodied and smooth. Flavors of peanut butter, jelly and light bread with a smooth lingering PB&J finish.
Sample at EBF. Pours light brown with a beige head. Aroma is caramel, peanut butter. Taste is caramel, peanut butter, raspberry jam. A bit thin, but it does replicate a pb&j pretty well.

Tasted from draft. Pours a clear amber with off white head. Honestly smells like a peanut butter and jelly sandwich. You get nice nutty and fruity aroma. Taste is also just like a PB&J. Crazy. Peanut butter flavor with some fruity berry notes. Some earthy and caramel flavor as well. Really interesting and great tasting beer. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Red/garnet in color with a white head that laces nicely. Smells of peanut butter and biscuit. Taste has distinct nuttiness followed by a moderate sweetness. Finishes clean across the palate.
This is what it says... A PB&J Brown Ale.. A Sweet and nutty brown ale. This beer has a very unique taste that of a PB&J in a bottle that gets you drunk.. What not more to love?

Clear amber brown colour, off-white head. Vegetal aroma, peanut and caramel. Sweet flavour, candy, caramel, malts, light sour hint. Finish sour and sweet candy (rode matten).(from draught @ CBC green session, Copenhagen 2014. Thanks for sharing todays beers, RateBeer crew!)
Julie says it is very nice smooth malty nutty ale not to bitter. Julie says well balance. She gives a 3.8

UPDATED: NOV 29, 2014 Sorcery. Thick slabs of peanut butter wall in a raspberry jammy quality and I dont even know how this is possible.

Like it tastes exactly like pbj in beer form. The only thing I can knock is that this isnt exactly my dream beer flavor combo.

What the hell.

There is some pretty have keg variation because I tried this again last night and the peanut butter was way less prevalent in favor of a fruition sweetness that detracted from the beers quality.  Knocking it down to a middle ground for now.

Poured from a tap. Medium brown color, small off white head. Roasted malt a peanut aroma. Light body with a mild peanut butter flavor and a medium finish. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Tap at CBC 2014. Beer in the glass brownish, small head. Spicy-malty aroma. Starts intense malty, fine spicy, light sweetish background. Notes of some herbs. Finish light sourish. Interesting.

Keg at the Copenhagen Beer Celebration 2014, green session. 03/05/2014. Clouded red / amber coloured pour with an off white head. Aroma is raspberry jelly, jam and nutty malts. Flavour is Semi-sweet medium nutty, light caramel and toasted malts, nice raspberry jam, light tart raspberry. Palate is crisp, tart and sharp with some citric acid. Decent beer.

Draught @ CBC 2014 [ Green Session ]. - Copenhagen Beer Celebration 2014, Sparta Hallen, Gunnar Nu Hansens Plads 11, 2100 Copenhagen, Denmark [ As Funky Buddha No Crusts ].Clear medium amber orange color with a average, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, caramel, candy, sweet - sour berry tart note. Flavour is moderate to heavy sweet and light light acidic with a long duration, sweet malt, sweet berry - candy. Body is medium, texture is watery, carbonation is soft. [20140503]

Sample @ CBC 2014. Pours hazy amber with a small tan head. Aroma is peanut butter, some sweet and tart raspberries, light malty notes. Taste is nutty, light raspberries and light malty, crisp nutty finish. Medium bodied.
Had on draft at tap n grind. Pour was dark with light tan head. The jelly was light but had nice peanut better aromas. Very sweet and tasty.
On tap at CBC 2014. Amber with off white head. Aroma and taste is fairly dry, some berries, peanuts, soil, metal, nuts, raspberries and some acidity
Draught at Mikkeller & Friends. Black with a tan head. Aroma medium malty (caramel, roasted, notes of jelly and peanut butter). Flavor medium+ sweet, light bitter. Medium body.
CBC. Clear amber with an off-white head. Aroma is sweet, malty, caramel and a hint of raspberries. Flavor is quite sweet and moderate bitter. Sweet finish. 030514
Draft. Black pour with tan head. Grape jelly and light peanut better aromas. Sweet grape and light peanut and other sweet malt tones.

On tap at the brewery in February. Pours a hazy deep orange/brown with a small tan head. The smell is a big grape nose. The taste is grape jelly, some alcohol. Medium body, a bit syrupy with active carbonation.

3rd May 2014CBC Session 4. Hazy deep amber beer, small pale cream coloured head. Palate is light and crispy. A tart generic fruitiness with a touch of floral rosehips. Not getting much peanut butter. Light crisp finish. Interesting!

Tap. Slighlly hazy deep brown body with a small tan head. Aroma of citrus, nuts, slightly toasted malt and caramel. Sweet flavor that ends up more dry and bitter. Medium bodied, oily texture and soft carb. An excellent Brown.
Nose is peanut butter, red currant, later weak smoke, weak cola, feel is mediumbroad, taste is peanut butter, some red berries acidity, earth, late rubber note
Draught at CBC 2014. Clear brown - offwhite head. Sweetness, candy, peanut, light fatness, tobacco, butterness, acid notes, nutty, caramel, peachy notes, citrus.

Tap @ CBC, 14. Hazy dark brown with small tan head. Aroma is malt, caramel, nuts and a little "labre larver". Flavour is malt, caramel, nut, medium sweet, little "labre larver", toasted, hop and a little bitter.

Draught sample at Copenhagen Beer Celebration 2014. 4th Session. Pours red copper with a medium head, aroma of vanilla, caramel, malt, flavor is slightly sour with vanilla, caramel and malt, medium bodied.
Draught at CBC 2014. Dark amber colour with a tan head. Aroma and flavour of caramel, peanut butter, malt and fruit,
From tap. Pours clear and golden orange with a small tan head. Aroma is fruity. Peachy and citrusy. Mango and passion fruity. Floral.sweet and lingering fruity into the finish.

Draught CBC 2014. Dark ambewr coloured. UNclear. Dense beige head. Aroma. Sweetness, caramel, peanut, herbs. Flavour. Full of peanut butter, caramel, sweetness, herbs, light roast. medium boedied. Ends light bitter and penutish.

[5/3/14] Draught sample at Copenhagen Beer Celebration. 4th session. Amber. Aroma of peanut butter and jelly. Sweetish flavor of peanut butter, berry jelly, a bit of fruitiness and a light sourish note. Medium-bodied.

Draught at CBC 2014. Pours red-brown with a medium-sized off-white head. Taste is of caramel, malt, hops and citric fruits. Medium body and soft carbonation. Smooth with a bitter tangy aftertaste that sticks around for a while.
At CBC. Hazy brown colour with off-white head. Fruity, raspberry aroma. Acid, roasted, fruity taste. Medium body.
Tap @ CBC, cph. Slightly hazy, brown, small off white head, some lacing. Malty, caramel, jam, nutty. Taste of jam and peanuts. Nice.

Draught at CBC 2014.
Hazy orange-brown coloured with a small off-white head.
Fruity and of caramel and berries.
Fruity flavour of caramel and berries.
Fruity finish.

Draught @ CBC 2014. Pours brown with a small offwhite head. Aroma of malt, caramel, sweet tart fruit, peanut butter, candy. Flavor is malts, sweet caramel, tart fruity. peanut butter. Medium body, soft carbonation. 030514

Sample at CBC 2014. 

Almost clear amber with a small head. Aroma and taste of grass, caramel, some peanuts and something strange like boiled vegetables. Not a great one.

Sampled @ CBC 2014. Clear autumnal reddish color, medium sized off-white to beige head. Smell and taste are herbal, spicy, slightly flowers, dirt, plants, slightly sourish. Average body and carbonation. Not my thing at all.
Sample at CBC. Pours a cloudy golden With a white head. Aroma has malty sweetness and roastiness. Taste has sour notes at the start, balanced by roastiness and caramel.

Fad på CBC: Brunlig uklar øl med et fint skumhoved. Mærkelig duft som en amerikaner nok ville kalde peanutbutter and jelly. for mig kan jordnødderne ikke rigtig anes og det bliver bare en sød omgang stads. Smagen er igen mærkelig sød. Ikke min type.
Draft at CBC 2014. Pours clear brown with a ring tan head. Aroma is vegetal, corn, caramel and light herbs. Flavor is moderate sweet and bitter. Medium bodied with light carbonation. Not good.
Sample @ CBC 14. Pours a clear amber beer with a small off white head. Aroma and flavor are both disgusting. Rotten veggies, bad stuff and onions. Bad.

Tap @ CBC 2014. Pours clear amber with a small, creamy, off-white head. Aroma has caramel, grass, light chalky, sulphur . High carbonation, fine dry and fairly light mouthfeel. Flavour has caramel, grass, chalky. Not very good.

CBC 2014
Pours amber brown low off white head
Aromas of raspberries, bready malts, sweet fruits
Taste has liqourise n raspberries, caramel

Pours cloudy reddish with low off-white head. Aroma of peanut butter, strawberry jam and rye bread... PBJ, simply put. Taste is sweetish and jam-like, some peanut. Body is light and sticky with soft carbonation.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Tap at the Copenhagen beer festival... Dark red brown... Thin tan lacing... Light Vegative nose... Sweet fruits... Berry... Quite bitter

Échantillonné du Extreme beer fest 2014: Limpression dêtre devant une tartinade de beurre darachides et gelée de framboises maisons sur pain intégral est tellement forte quon oublie vite être devant un liquide. Le savoir-faire lemporte sur lélégance.
Well another beer by FB that doesnt lie about what it tastes like. Grape jelly and peanuts on the aroma. Taste is highly sweet and grape jammy with some salty peanuts on the back end.

Draft at hunahpu hangover 2014. Huge fruit jam and marmalade nose. Moderate peanut butter with some light chocolate and cocoa powder. Medium to dry finish with a weird tartness to it. This particular one didnt live up to the hype, especially with the tartness. Makes me wonder if something was off with this batch.

Growler thanks to Nick! Pours a cloudy brown with beige head that leaves spotty lacing. The aroma is strong grape jam and peanuts. Medium mouthfeel with strong jam and light peanuts with sweet finish. Wow pb and j in a glass. So good.

Une robe acajou. Une mousse petite mais belle et tenace. Un nez hallucinant de pain rôti sur lequel dégouline un mélange de confiture et de beurre darachides crémeux. Limpression est terriblement réussie et terriblement efficace. Les yeux fermés, on dirait que je retombe en enfance, un matin du mois daoût, dans le camp de pêche, lorsque ma mère nous tartinait cette sublime recette qui résiste au temps. Le goût est aussi authentique avec cette confiture de fraises légèrement sucrée et ce beurre de cacahuètes légèrement fondu. Calisse, je suis flabergasté. Le palais est aussi impressionnant. La texture est légèrement collante tandis que le corps est bien traversée par les bulles. Jaime cette sensation! En finale, rien pour écoeurer et tout pour me faire passer une fin de journée des plus agréables. Après une journée de travail, une baignade dans locéan et une balade de 20 minutes en voiture, je suis, en ce moment, le plus heureux des Slovaques.

Draft @ GABF 2013. Pours a black color with a small tan head. Has a roasted malty weak raspberry chocolate aroma. Roasted malty chocolate and raspberry flavor. Has a roasted malty chocolate and raspberry finish.

An ale that tastes and smells just like the iconic sandwich! Starting with the intense aroma of creamy peanut butter mingling with mixed berry jam. Just like mom used to make! 

Such an interesting beer. Ive had several things from Funky Buddha and Im looking forward to my first sip of No Crusts. I have heard fantastic things about it. I had the Bonita Applebum for the first time yesterday and I was blown away by that; and people were saying Its great, but its no No Crusts.

Poured from a growler, thanks Bacterial/Jeff! Aroma was decent peanut butter but wasnt too strong, lacked the necessary palate or sweetness for me to get the jam out of it. It wasnt bad but didnt live up to my expectations.

Sample at GABF. Well as others have said - pretty damn close to a PB&J. Aroma is roasted nutty. The taste is where the sweet jam comes in. Nice attempt that succeeded where others have failed miserably. Top notch brown ale and good to very good overall.

Pour from a growler on Darkness Eve 2013. Had high hopes for this one and traded some really nice beer for it, but what I got was something pretty thin, had a hint of peanut butter and maybe a jam raspberry finish. Underwhelming. Maybe the growler was bad (though the carbonation was just fine)?
DK how you infuse a beer with pb&j btu it smells but doesnt taste like pb&j, not a huge fan of pb&j.

UPDATED: OCT 9, 2015 GABF 2013. Pours a brownish black appearance with a tan head. Big chocolate and peanut butter aroma that is pretty inviting. Fairly thin body. A bit roasty, chocolate, vanilla, light caramel, nutty flavor. Kind of a cool beer but doesnt blow my mind. (3.8) GABF: Re-rate: kind of twangy (3.2).

Surprised others have rated this so highly. Peanuts and jammy berries are definitely apparent, but even though I love peanut butter, I dont love this. Sticky sweet in the mouth and finish. Flavor profile is excessively sweet and not enjoyable for much more than a few sips.
On tap at GABF 2013, just like a peanut butter and jelly sandwich aroma with some extra roasted nut aroma. Taste is nutty and some light sweet jam, medium body.

On tap @ GABF. Almost black in color with a khaki head. Nose is really strange. A tobacco and roasted malt forward aroma. Plenty of coffee, some blueberry, and sweet berry jam. Mild sweetness. Flavor is heavy on the coffee grounds. Some sweet jam/jelly, roast, toast, and a bit of tobacco. Not sure I really got this one.

Draft at GABF. Creamy khaki head and medium to dark brown body. Aroma of peanut butter powder, light caramel, and sweet jam. Taste is a delicious PB&J that brings the full range of associated flavors but doesnt strain either one. Peanut isnt too roasty or burnt. Grape jelly isnt too sweet. And the grainy bread note isnt too yeasty. I love this stuff and am already jonesing for more. Hoping for friend to get bottles in Florida and bring them back.

Draft at GABF. Pour is deep brown with a frothy brown head and good lacing. Huge nutty, semi-sweet chocolatey, lacto, vanilla cream, anise, coconut, and light roasty aroma. Taste is really crazy and interesting - sweet grape jelly and nutty malt, a bit roasty and chocolatey, but really does taste like a PB&J in a glass. Syrupy mouthfeel with soft carbonation. Really cool beer and another treat from this brewery.
Draft. Need label. Pours dark with tan head. Nose and taste of peanut butter, grape jelly, light toasted chocolate and toasted peanut. Medium body.

Growler. The pour is brown. The aroma is all peanut butter. The taste is a little light and thin, but heavy peanut butter. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

32 oz. growler served in a wine glass. Big thanks to immobliseme for the share.

A: Pours a dark brown color with a light tan head forming on the pour. It recedes a to thin ring. Some mild soapy lace left down the edges of the glass.

S: Weird. Peanut butter sweetness with a straight peanut and light grape jelly notes. Dried bread crust malt notes as well.

T: Same as the nose. Lots of whole wheat bread and grain with peanuts and grape jelly notes. Sweetness and fruitiness mix together.

M: Medium to thin bodied with a medium carbonation level. Sweet finish.

O: A very odd beer and glad I was able to try it. Much better than the Shorts take on it as everyone Ive had by them as they had a faint plastic note to them. Pretty well executed, but the small pour I had was enough for me. Thanks, Todd!

Serving type: growler

09-06-2013

Big thanks to diego for this growler

Poured dirt brown with very little head.

Smell of peanuts and Concorde grapes

Flavor waa extremely bready..,wheat bread to be.more descriptive haha. They really nailed the pbj flavor. Grape jelly was more predominant than the peanut but was def present.

Growler thanks to Matt! Opens with a big pop and is a slow motion delayed action gusher. Pours opaque dark brown with a very large creamy brown head and nice lacing. Aroma is caramel, grape jelly, peanuts , cardboard. Flavor is the same, not as sweet as I was expecting, touch of bitterness, touch of astringence. Definitely interesting. Medium body.

Growler shared by imobiliseme. Thanks, Todd. Pours a richer amber brownish pour, a nice haziness with some gentle amber glow on the edges. A frothy tannish head dies to a film, laces small. Aromas are peanuts, gentle dark and red fruit. Some brown malt, touches of toast, bread, and richer earthy peanut crunch. Initial is a bit more mellow in body, rich peanut butter, peanut crunch, earthy, a bit toasty. Some gentle cocoa, mellow red and dark fruit. Some bready and brown malt. Middle is gentle red and dark fruit, a touch seedy and sweet. It never really develops for me. The beer is very peanut dominant. Backend is a bit sweet, earthy and peanut driven. Some toast, biscuit, and more peanut. Finish is a bit more nutty, bready, gentle toast. Neat beer. Very unique. I wouldnt call it an amazing beer though. Solid, nifty experiment.

Odd. It really is like pb&j. Amazing. Do I want this in a beer? I'm not sure but if I did they hit a home run. Aroma light jelly and peanut butter taste is the same it's a sandwich which sat for a couple hours. Sweet flavor peanut flavor. Amazing. How do you do this. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

draft at the brewery. Darkish brown, small head. Peanut butter, chocolate and maybe a hint of vinegar in the aroma. Some notes of the jelly on the tongue but peanut butter also. There are some berries buried underneath this all. This is a very complex and a really awesome brown ale.

UPDATED: JUL 29, 2013 Fresh growler. Peanut butter aroma galore! Yeah, its definitely freshly churned peanut butter (smooth, not chunky), and not the nuts themselves. Jelly shows up more prominently as the beer warms.  

Jammy grape jelly with peanuts not far behind; brown ale base provides support without getting in the way. Not sweet at all. Demonstrates mastery of brewing with special ingredients. If youre an avid home brewer, No Crusts will incite your best Keanu Reeves impersonation as you step back and say "Whoa..." 

This is brewing art, ladies and gents.  And its exactly what Ive come to expect from Funky Buddha.
Unholy Fucking Shit; this was like drinking a Peanut and Jelly Sandwich! Gotta love Philly Beer Week! Love Funky Buddha too!

On tap at Funky Buddha Boca. Pours black with a brown head and great aroma of straight peanut butter sandwich. Taste is delicious, more straight peanut butter and jelly with some roasted malt notes. Have to try it once, interesting brew that features peanut butter beautifully, well done

Draft at Funky Buddha. Snifter. Pours as a brown ale with dark brown heady pour. No lacing. Nose is truly peanut butter, roasted peanuts and berries. The taste is more peanut butter than jelly but the finish is sweet with a hint of berries. Mouth is very smooth and creamy. Slight carbonation. So damn good and unique.
UPDATED: JUN 19, 2013 On draft at brewery, novelty points definitely awarded. Tasts like toast and grape jelly. Its crazy, definitely went for a second glass

Very unique!  Hints of grape and strawberry jam with roasted peanut butter and toasted bread.   

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Hazy brown color with a small, light tan head that left nice lacing on the glass.  Aroma of roasted malts, light cocoa, peanut butter, toast, and jelly  Taste of caramel malts, roast, peanut, and seemingly grape jelly.  Exceeded expectations.

On tap at brewery grand opening...nice roasted peanut aroma with the same up front in the taste followed by grape jelly flavor.  Really tastes like PBJ.  Cant say I could drink much of this but definitely an awesome beer to try!
Bottle. Pours clear brown with not much head. Big peanut aroma. Taste like hoppy roasted peanuts slight sweet jelly

Tap at Funky Buddhas 2nd year anniversary. Dark brown, tan head. Nose and taste are peanut butter sandwich, without the jelly. Mouthfeel is fairly thin, which is fine for a brown ale, but if the body were thicker Id have enjoyed this even more.

Draft at Prohibition Taproom in Philadelphia, PA. 

Pours a dark amber, almost brown color with golden orange edges and a  two finger white head that slowly fades into a lasting ring.

Another dessert beer aroma nailed by Funky Buddha.  Smells just like a peanut butter and jelly sandwich but unfortunately not like a beer.  Its odd thats its called No Crusts because bread crust is one of the strongest characteristics of the nose.  Lots of freshly baked bread with roasted peanut and jammy jelly.   Strong roasted nut character followed by welchs grape.   A bit seedy as well.  Crazy that they replicated the aroma of one of my favorite meals but I wish that it smelled(and tasted) a bit more like beer. 

Medium bodied with a nice balance of toasted peanut, sweet, slightly tart jelly and fresh bread.  Roasted with lots of peanut flavor up front along with slightly smoked malt undertones.  More peanut than peanut butter but it still replicates the flavor pretty well.  This is followed by fresh baked bread (including  crust) and a really prominent sweet, tart jam presence in the finish.   The jelly portion of the beer is really overpowering after a few ounces and provides a lingering unpleasant aftertaste.  The subtle roasted malt notes were the only element that made it taste like a brown ale.  Other than that it tastes more like a  good alcoholic dessert drink than a beer.  Decent but nowhere near as good as some of their other experimental beers.

On draft at Churchkey in D.C.

The beer is russet brown with a half inch of head. The aroma is shocking and hilarious. I would literally think one was holding a PB&J sandwich under my nose if this were a blind test. Very impressive. The flavor follows suit. I wish I could go more in depth, but this is a straightforward brew - it smells and tastes like a PB&J beer. Light to medium bodied. Not something I would drink in quantity, but I highly recommend trying this if you have the opportunity.

On tap at Churchkey.  Served in a mini snifter.  Pours a moderate brown color with a short head and a bit of lacing.  The nose carries some peanut butter and jelly.  Surprise, surprise.  The peanut butter component takes over, with just a bit of berry in the background.  Flavor has mild fruit and more peanut.  A bit one-dimensional, and not my favorite dimension at that.  Medium body with a semi-dry finish.  Just okay.
Draft. Hazy brown color, tan edge head. Aroma of pb&j with subtle crusts. Taste is sweet grapes, caramel.

Draft at Churchkey for the Bluejacket/Funky Buddha/Cigar City event during SAVOR week. Poured a light brown color, with a red tint or so, small wispy head. Aroma was notes of peanut and some grape jelly - really captured the smell of a peanut butter and jelly sandwich. Flavor is not nearly as enjoyable, but I did enjoy the sweet fruit and touch of roast.

Draft.  Clear dark brown body with small beige head.  Aroma is moderately sweet, grape jelly, peanut butter/salt.  Taste is moderately sweet, milk chocolate, peanut/salt, grape jelly, caramel.  Medium body, some stickiness.

Tap at CK. Clear maroon pour with minimal head. Nose is husky circus peanut shells with subtle grape jam. Taste is watery, some sharp peanut skin, tangy detergent. Thick circus peanut shells. Tangy and soapy weak finish. Not a fan. Why would anyone want to brew with peanuts ever. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

On tap at the Prohibition Taproom.  Dark auburn brown with a haze.  Nose is peanut, carob and grape jelly with hints of raspberry.  Medium body with a crisp tingle.  Taste is earthy peanut, lightly sour, red berries and grape.  Dry finish with hints of bitter coffee bean and Nutella.  Flavors change with every sip.  Cool brew.

Draft at prohibition. Pours a deep, murky brown body with thin carbonated lacing. Aroma is bready, crusts actually, and peanut butter. Mouthfeel is incredible - a truly unique beer which perfectly captures the peanut butter and jelly sandwich.

Pours amber somewhat translucent amber with a smaller tan head. The aroma is magnificent, tons of sweet peanut butter and and light berry notes for the jelly so potent. The flavor of sweet nutty notes settle nicely on the tongue with a berry ending, not sweet or overpowering, just there to say hello. Wow, cant believe this is a brown ale.

UPDATED: JUN 6, 2012 On draft at Prohibition. Pours brown w/ thin khaki head. Aroma is dark chocolate, nuts, dark cherries. Taste is sweet peanut shells, hints of cherries, roasted malts. Basically tastes and smells like what youd think. Very unique and delicious 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Murky muddy brown, thin light tan head.  Peanuts, caramel, miscellaneous nutty notes, bready malts and a little bit of grape jelly.  Id prefer a bit more grape jelly in the flavor as the nuttiness really takes over. Medium to full bodied, moderate carbonation.  Interesting, but I cant say Id ever want to drink this again.
Draft at Capones . nose is strong with Spainsh peanuts and malty overtones, first sip is interesting with a dry roasted peanut flavor with slight fruit paste finis slighty sweet. not bad.

UPDATED: JUN 5, 2012 Pours a murky amber with brown spirals mid glass, small lacing and head. Aromas of chunky peanut butter, nutella, milk chocolate. Taste is filled with creamy peanut butter, welchs grape jelly, damn, never thought a beer could taste like a pb&j on some wonder bread. This one was dead on.

Didnt take notes on this and it was kind of mashed between the other ones so I dont have a lot of details.  Nose was really nice bread crust with a sweet, earthy quality that I could definitely call peanut-butter like.  Mouth is on the thin side, a solid brown ale with really fresh bread and peanut qualities.  Good, good stuff.  I really like how clearly this brewery is able to highlight specific flavors/components.

Pours deep amber with a medium tan head.  Aroma has light peanut butter...nutty...malty...some hazelnut...a bit like nutella.  Flavor has more peanut butter but not sweet...some roastiness.  Mouthfeel is medium and lively with a nutty/roasty finish.
On draft at Capones. Pours a deep caramel amber with a small off white head. Aroma of peanut butter, welches grape jelly, and wonder bread. Taste is identical to the taste.

Bottle 650 ml, tasted in October last year. Quite a big gusher, lost maybe a quarter of the bottle. Pours muddy brown. Huge aroma of fresh and roasted peanuts (how the hell did they manage to get it like that!). Taste holds the same peanuts, jam, sour cherries. An obvious infection in this beer, makes me think of Jolly Pumpkin. Not at all an unpleasant beer, but I would really like to have it as the brewers intended.

Draft: Poured a blackened brown with a tan colored head. Aroma was similar to a peanut butter and jelly sandwich. Taste was a mix of peanut butter and malt, there was also a fruitiness reminding me of the sandwich it was designed after.

Pouring at the Saturday afternoon session of EBF.  Pours a clear brown with a medium sized beige to tan head.  Wheat bread is the first thing that hits me, then dusty peanut butter.  The flavor finishes the sandwich, starting off tasting exactly like Welches grape jelly.  Medium bodied, the peanut butter flavor shows up slows, bringing the taste of bread with it.  Remarkable.

12 oz. bottle.  Pours a hazy brown color with a medium sized off white head.  The aroma was as advertised; roasted peanut butter and berry jelly.  Slight tart, but good overall.  The flavor is more of the same; peanut butter and jelly.  It was amazing that they could get the flavors into a beer.  Medium bodied and interesting.  Cool label too.

A second bottle I opened had some infection unfortunately.  It foamed forever open opening.  More acidity and tart notes.  The peanut butter came through nicely, but the jelly component was soured and distracted some.

Alright a catchy name. Pour is dark and aroma of peanuts. Taste is definitely peanut butter and jelly, sweet, not complex. Alcohol masked well. Worth trying once ! OK if you are into extreme fringed beers, if not stay with an unflavored CRMA !

Bottle from Biggsbowler.   My first Funky Buddha beer and my first PB&J inspired brew.  Im not going to bother describing this beer, because if you have ever eaten a peanut butter and jelly sandwich, then you know exactly how this beer smells and tastes.  Its actually quite impressive how accurate this beer is.  I dont know how they did, but Im glad they did.  Obviously a little gimmicky and probably something  I wouldnt buy a case of, but even with the strange flavor infusion, it remains balanced, easily drinkable with a medium body and soft carbonation.

Bottle shared by alexsdad06. Poured a clear brown color with a huge frothy off-white head that mostly lasted with good lacing. Moderate toasted sweet nut, grape jelly and soap aroma. Medium body with a bitter texture and lively carbonation. Balanced bittersweet flavor with a medium bittersweet finish of moderate duration. Complex infected brew.

Draft @ Treasure Coast beer fest. Pours dark brown color with tan head. Smells and tastes like peanut butter and grape jelly. I taste crusts in there!!! Medium body with moderate carbonation. These PB&J beers are just too wierd for me, Im not a big fan.
bottle, thanks to ericandersnavy, amber brown color with  that strange green pinto bean or boiled peanut aroma, flavor has some bready nut and toasted grains, fruity grain finish

Thanks to ericandersnavy for sharing this bottle.

The beer pours a brownish color with a tan head. The aroma is very nice. I get a lot of peanut butter notes with some grape jelly notes. Someone at the table also said they thought the beer smelled like refried pinto beans, which I could see after using some imagination. 

The flavor has a lot of peanut butter and hazelnut character to it. I also get a lot of caramel and toffee with some cocoa mixed in. Once again, there is a little bit of jelly character to the flavor. Somewhat surprisingly, this beer definitely reminds me of a peanut butter and jelly sandwich.

Medium mouthfeel and medium carbonation. 

This is what I imagine Shorts was aiming for when they brewed PB&J. If they could ever release a batch that wasnt infected, maybe I could confirm that.

(22oz bottle, courtesy of ericandersnavy)  Pours a cloudy amber-brown body with a small beige head.  Aroma of organic peanut butter and grape jam.  Flavor of peanut butter, caramel, bread, and grape jam.

(Bottle) Pours muddy brown with a nougat coloured head. The aroma holds roasted peanut up front with light fruity/black currant and acidic undertones. Light malt roast and toast in the background. The flavour is light sweet, light bitter and light to medium acidic. Currant, peanuts and berries. The mouthfeel is tart and light round with medium carbonation. Dry peanuts, hop bitterness and tart berries on the finish. Near medium bodied.

(12oz bottle thanks to jyoungsbcp) cloudy orange with a nice fine tan bubbles head. Nose of peanut butter, fresh fruit jelly, strawberry, raspberry compote, crusts and all like a PB&J sandwich. Taste of PB&J sandwich, sweet white bread, crust, lightly toasty, peanut shells, strawberry jelly, well carbonated, prickly palate.

Bottle, pours deep dark brown with almost no off white head... the aroma is lots peanut butter, flowers, acidic... the flavor is lots peanuts, soft, roasted malt, caramel, nuts..... the mouthfeel is soft and sweet.... full body....

Botella. Cloudy dark brown colour, small beige head. Peanutty funky berry jam dark malty caramel spiced aroma. Good mouthfeel. Spiced dark malty peanut bit funky like sweet fruity jam like flavour. Spiced peanut malty bitter finish. Strange quite interesting brew.

Growler provided by Hopscotch. Thanks a mill man! It pours hazy brown with a medium tan head. Unfortunately this was gushing but I managed to get 3 decent glasses. The aroma is light acidic and lacto like and has strong notes of toasted caramel and roasted malt. Quite heavy nutty notes of peanuts and has some funky notes in the back. The flavour is quite nutty, with notes of fruit, roasted malt, caramel and has some funky notes that might come from the jelly. Sweet fruity and nutty finish.

Had this on the eve of the August 27th JOs bottle release. Big thanks to Cam for bringing this. ~2-3 oz from a tasting snifter.

3.5 A: Hazed light brown color. One finger frothy light beige head.

4.5 S: This certainly delivers on the name. Tons of grape jelly. Crunchy peanut butter behind that. Light breadiness indicative of an actual PBJ.

3.5 T: As good as the nose is, the taste is disappointing. It is still a good beer, but it tastes watered down. Way less jelly and a lot less peanut butter. Still a PBJ, put one using light peanut butter and sugar free jelly.

2.5 M: Light to lighter medium body. Over carbonated by a decent amount. This is the major failure of this beer. I logically crave a chewy, stick to your mouthtop type of body - rich and velvety, but that isnt what I got.

3.5 D: Good beer, but the mouthfeel is far too light and the taste is lacking power.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 08-31-2011 03:39:27

Thanks to St.Fun for sharing this.  Oh yea thanks to urbancaver for sharing the night prior tho it was the bottom of the bottle.  This is one hell of a way to spice up a standard brown ale.  Brown pour.  Aroma is PB&J.  So is the flavor.  Quite amazing actually, bready malts, peanut and grape jam

12oz. Bottle:  Got in trade from biggsbowler; THANKS Randall!  Amazing aroma of peanut-butter and jelly on wheat, grape jelly, dry roasted peanuts, and bread.  Could not smell more like a real PB&J.  Poured deep amber/brown in color with a large brown head that diminished but lasted throughout.  Cloudy.  Very sparkling.  Full of tiny and small particles throughout.  Flavor is medium sweet.  Tastes like it smells, like a PB&J.  Flavors of grape, jelly, salty dry roasted peanuts, wheat bread, and some malt.  Medium body.  Lightly dry texture.  Average carbonation.  PB&J, grape jelly, dry roasted salty peanut, wheat bread finish is dry.

Fruit in the Room 2011. Saw this on the tap list and was stoked. Nose is pure PB&J. Strawberry jam mixed with a creamy peanut butter nose. Some malt and light alcohol on the nose too. Somewhat grainy giving it that bready character to complete the sandwich. Crazy. Poured pretty dark with a thin light brown head. Tasted like a light peanut butter sandwich. Some strawberry sweetness was detected on the initial taste but seemed to dissipate rather quickly on the taste buds. Lots of peanuts though. Good stuff that everyone who likes PB&Js should try at least once.
Poured a dark brown color with a tan head to it. Smells just like a PB&J sandwich, Im shocked. Taste was similar to the smell with a sweet jelly part coming out in the back. Very interesting brew.

Bottle from Hopscotch. Thanks Eric! Pours dark amber brown with a dissipating tan head. Bottled gushed which was a concern. Smells just like a PB & J sandwich on wheat bread. I should know, I have three kids and make these fucking these all week long. Medium bodied with semi soft, fine carbonation. Flavor of grape jelly, peanut butter, and bready malts. Could use a bit more residual sugars to mimic the real thing. Tastes great, but smells amazing. Get the two to align and watch out.

The aroma is amazing, full on peanut butter and jelly sandwich. Flavor is a little weak in my opinion, but Smooth, palate, kind of like it coats the mouth. Thanks so much hopscotch andsmitty for sharing this.

Funky Buddha no crusts. 12oz bottle courtesy of Eric for sending this our way... Pours a a semi muddled brown ale-like pour, semi- transparent in nature, and topped with a thin wispy faded lighter beige head... Aroma of salted peanut shells upfront and remain predominantly so with softer fruit undertones which are held mostly in check by the assertive peanut forwardness.... Semi-sweet flavor profile with more fresh peanut shells with a backing saltiness perspective towards the backend. Fruits, lending more towards the berry side of the house, while remaining somewhat sweet and then transitioning back to a salted peanut focus. Medium bodied with adequate carbonation. One extra point on the overall score for novelty and nailing the peanut nature.
8/4/7/3/15

The line for this one at St Pete Craft Beer Expo was almost out the door and around the corner.  There is a reason why.  Pours a dark brown with a small off-tan head.  Smells like a Kindergartners lunchbox.  Nose is well, peanut butter and jelly.  The peanuts come out as roasted peanuts with hints of earth, but the jelly expresses itself better than Smuckers could hope for.  Flavor is similar- peanut butter with hints of earth in the foreground and a sweet grape presence that does not let time pass before coming into the mid and the finish.  After the jelly has faded away, the peanut butter comes back for an encore.  Simply amazing how the do this.  The most remarkable thing about this beer is the balance it exhibits- no one component is the star of the show, the stage is shared equally.

Bottle pours brown color with off white head.  Aroma is strong peanut butter note.  I really dont get the jelly in the nose at all.  The peanut butter is definitely there.  Medium mouthfeel.  Flavor has the jelly upfront, has a touch of the peanut butter and finishes with a slight metallic note.  I dont understand how the nose mainly has peanut butter and the flavor mainly has the jelly. But is does.  An above average beer.  Not mind blowing.

On tap at Funky Buddha. Ive never liked PB&J sandwiches because they never tasted as good as this beer. Ive had this beer at least four times and, it just gets better and better. As soon as you move your nose towards the rim of the glass, the peanut butter hits you square in the face. I pushed the glass away and brought it back for another sniff. Then, I just stared at it for a couple of minutes. I wasnt sure what I was going to do. It smelled so AMAZING!!! Finally, I got the courage to drink some. Between the peanut butter and grape jelly, I truly understood why my brother took his time, making each sandwich with just the right amounts. From start to finish, this better doesnt get better. Oh no, it stays great throughout each sip. Also, I would pour this beer down Selma Hayeks chest and drink it off her toes. Yes, its that good.

Pours a dark brown color with a a minimal head that is gone very quickly.  The nose is exactly what you might think.  It smells like peanut butter, jelly and wheat bread.  The taste is pretty much the same rich peanut butter and strawberry jelly like taste.  You even taste the bread in there.  Crusts included.  The beer is super rich.  I can only drink one but damn is it enjoyable.  This tops the cake for the beer that tastes the most like what it says its suppose to taste like.

On tap at the Funky Buddha.  Murky reddish brown pour with a small white head.  I thought the MBCP nose was incredible but the No Crust is down right insane.  Total freakin chunky roasted peanut butter with undercurrents of dried berries.  The taste is so cool.  Massive peanut butter flavors offset by mixed berry jam, apricots, and blackberries.  Kudos to Kevin, Ryan, and the rest of the Buddha crew....

Poured a dark hazy brown on draft at the Buddha.  Seriously is that an old school PB&J sandwich I smell?  It is, takes me back to the lunches my mom used to make.  First sip was wow, how did they capture wheat bread so nicely, tasted like wheat bread throughout with the reminance of. Peanut butter (almost like a reeses aftertaste) and grape jelly.  Overall an interesting beer, I did want a nice glass of cold milk afterwards.

This poured a murkly brown color with a huge volcanoing beige head. Aroma was almost all jelly, strawberry and raspberry sweet fruit, with light notes and grian and peanutes. Flavor was also more on the fruity jelly side, peanuts are there but are faint compared to the fruit. Better than shorts but not quite as good as I was expected given the previous ratings.

Bottle shared by a generous individual during OBW 2011. Brown pour with a thin beige head. Aroma of berries, peanuts and Franks RedHot hot sauce. Malty flavor with with some peanut character and more of that tangy hot sauce now showing up in the flavor before a berry jelly finish. Not sure whats in there that my palate is detecting as wing sauce, but its a bit strange.

Sample from a bottle at Jackie Os as part of Ohio Brew Week. The beer is a murky reddish-brown color with a medium thin light tan head that recedes quickly. Partial rings of lacing on the glass. Aroma of roasted malt and a touch of horseradish. Medium body with flavors of roasted nuts, tart berry and grainy malt. The finish is grainy with a berry aftertaste. Something seemed off about the beer, I would like to try it again sometime.

UPDATED: JUL 24, 2011 bottle thanks to crusianbeer.  poured brownish with a beige head that lasted the life of the beer.  the moment that I smelled this beer it reminded me of boiled peanuts that can be bought in several places in Jville, fl.  the nose also seemed to remind me of raspberry jam.  the flavor was raspberry and "green" peanuts.  the body was light and dry with a tiny carbonation that left a pleasant feeling.  I am not sure about this one, maybe it was an off bottle.  Regardless, i am glad that i had the chance to try this one.  Thanks goes out to cruisans gf for bringing this one back.

Review from notes from tonight.
bottle thanks to my awesome girlfriend...split with ericandersnavy.
Poured a nice brown with about a finger of head...
The nose was.. a huge letdown. it honestly smelled like bean sprouts with a bit of peanut in there.... There was a fresh "green" aroma I could only link to the smell of bean sprouts, or alfalfa sprouts. There was a hint of raspberry... which I could say was jelly.
Taste was very sweet in the front, and finished a bit on the tart side. In the middle there was peanut flavor, but again, it seemed like fresh peanut flavor, green... eric said it best when he said it seemed like boiled peanuts. If anyone is from the south, it tasted like the boiled peanut water. No jelly at all. To be honest, i got mustard on the finish. Does anyone put mustard on a PB and J? I dont eat them, so I dont know, but I assume not. 
The mouthfeel was great, I cant remember the last time I had something with such tiny carbonation! it was like an explosion in my mouth, fantastic!
Overall though, this was a huge letdown. I was expecting so much, and got so little in return. I am glad actually have someone I tried this with that will rate it though... 
Maybe I had a bad bottle? I dont know, but from their other offerings i have tried and rated, this was a huge letdown.

Pour from a small bottle shared with Kan on a warm Chicago pre- Pitchfork  afternoon. Murky brown in color with a small tan head hefty aromas of dry peanuts. Medium thin body which was a bit disappointing. Brown semi sweet caramel malt flavors along side the nutty presence. Dont get much fruit jelly. A bit of earthiness to the mix. Pretty interesting.

Fresh bottle courtesy of hopscotch, thank you! wow..... how....... whaaa......... i dunno what to say. this is insane how much this beer tastes like pb and j, and is still delicious and drinkable at the same time. incredible. pours a lighter brown with lots of mahogony and orange hues, sparse khaki head, doesnt last long or leave much lacing. smell is awesome, perfect blend of pb and j, and that goes for the taste as well, though more so in the nose cause there is less beer influence. great nose, but just unreal flavor, very, very authentic peanut butter and fruity jelly profile. in the jelly im getting concord grape, raspberry,  and lighter hints of strawberry and blueberry preserves. the peanut butter smells like a raw, gritty, less processed and more natural peanut butter, not jiffy or some bullshit.  the body is great, sweet, slight bitterness in the finish to round it out, full feel and oily texture, great carbonation that seems to release the flavor and then disappear in the back palate for a smooth drinker.  extra point overall for ingenuity and such a great success at such a hard flavor combo. shorts and southern tier could both learn a thing or two from these guys, and i mean that nicely since i love all three breweries beers. this beer is great, these guys have flavoring brews down pat, nicely balanced and very expressive at the same time. terrificly funky stuff from the buddha.

Thanks to Casey for this... pours a nice dark amber brown, decent tan head... the nose is all roasted peanuts, salty, really great authentic peanuts, the jelly is hidden, dont get much but there is a sweet fruity note, smells great... the first is all roasted salty peanuts, its awesome, after that the taste dies down a bit, becomes a touch watery and dead on the finish, a touch of alcohol... really crushable the best pbj and beer Ive had, destroys Shorts version... for this type of beer, this is one of the best ones out there

Nose is amazing. Freshly ground peanut butter, hint of blueberry and cherry and light roasted malt. The color is sort of a reddish brown, quite dark. Flavor is like drinking a peanut butter and jelly sandwhich. Though the beer is called No Crusts there is actually something of crusty bread in the flavor from the malt. Sweet but not overly so, this is perfection in a glass, the only way this could be better is if it were a fuller bodied beer, an imperial version but nothing over 10%. Maybe. My favorite Buddha Beer to date. Kevin and Ryan have done it again.
UPDATED: JUL 31, 2011 Wow! Finally a beer that really tastes like a PB&J! Incredible. Eat your hearts out Shorts. This is how its done!!

Clarity: Clear for being Dark 
Hue: Brownish/Red in color 
Nose: Ughh Peanut Butter and Jelly Sandwich (Peanuts, Fruit, Bread) 

No Crusts was released June 10th at the Funky Buddha in Boca Raton, FL. 

This is exactly what a Peanut Butter and Jelly Beer should taste like. The nose leads to strong peanut butter with a slight hint of fruit. The taste has a nice attack of Jelly then then followed by the attack of the peanuts. 

Unlike other beer that I have had with peanut flavoring, this beer doesnt lay around and linger on your palate. 

A true treat. 

While I wouldnt be able to drink a bunch of these in one sitting, I will say that there isnt a single thing I would change about this beer.

Simply amazing! The guys at the  Funky Buddha have done it again. Putting together a great combo of peanut butter and jelly. Brings  you right back to childhood. The aroma, the flavor, the  whole experience of drinking this beer is just great. Right up there with Maple Bacon.

Wow, this beer is incredible. Murky brown with a thin tan head.  The nose is straight peanut butter and jelly, not sort of like peanut butter and jelly but full on stick your nose in a sandwich PB&J.  The mouth feel is full with gobs of fresh peanuts leading into a raspberry jam finish.  They hit this one dead on.

Draft - Deep murky brown, creamy off white head.  Thick warm gooey peanut butter aroma rides a soft current of raspberry jam throughout .  Reminds me of my kids favorite lunch as the flavor is truly dead on for a peanut butter and jelly sandwich.  A touch of sweet berry is expertly layered over the thick nuttiness from start to finish.  Medium bodied and smooth.  Unbelievable work of art...

Draft This beer rocks! Murky, dark caramel ale with a small, creamy, off-white head. Good retention. Smells just like a peanut butter and jelly sandwich. Not sort of like a PB&J sandwich; exactly like a PB&J sandwich. Medium-bodied with a milky mouthfeel and moderate carbonation. Tastes much like it smells  peanut butter, sweet preserves and a gentle kiss of acidity. Heavy on the peanut butter. Finishes fruity, nutty and lightly sweet. Ive tasted at least ten takes on a peanut butter or PB&J beer and this one, by far, is the most true to its aim. I didnt think something like this could be accomplished without artificial flavors or aromas. Spot-on, amazing brew!
